text: It truly is a challenge to find a well written Christian novel.  I've only found a few and this is one of them. I don't know who the protagonist, Will Chambers, is modeled after or if he's a composite, but I would like to meet him or them! He is a very brilliant, insightful attorney. The story expertly combines Will's natural abilities with God's supernatural interventions, weaving them together to hold the reader's attention until the story is resolved on the final page!

Grabbed from the beginning, this novel held me throughout. If you’re a lesser us better when it comes to government, this will drive you nuts. I found myself so engrossed with the drama unfolding that I began to join in with Will as he fights the system which had gone off the rails. A must read from an author who truly engages his readers.

As far as I'm concerned,  Mr. Parshall is #1 in the legal thriller  genre; better than John  Grisham.  He expertly weaves his stories through twists, turns and surprises. This story really carried me quickly through to the end. I read it in one day. I love that he includes Christianity in his books. His faith adds so much depth to the story. I very much enjoyed this book and highly recommend it. As a former legal secretary,  I'm always fascinated by legal thrillers.
This is the second in the 'Chambers of Justice' series by Craig Parshall.  As with the first one, this is well done.

The plot centers around the child welfare authorities trying to remove parental custody based on an allegation of terrible child abuse.  There are many twists and turns throughout.  The courtroom drama is great as is the rest.

In addition to being a legal thriller, this book explores many spiritual issues.  The lead character, Will Chambers is a fledgling Christian who is working on his spiritual life in addition to the action in the main storyline.  That part is well done also.
I will certainly be checking out more books in this series.  I recommend this book, but readers should probably start with 'The Resurrection File', which is the first one in this collection.
This is an excellent thriller series. Lots of action. You will not want to put it down. Read them in order.
The premise is scary. This is an engrossing book I recommend you read this when you have a lot of time to read it
Enjoyed this one as much as the first book in the series.  Holds your interest.  And the characters are very "real".
I look forward to the read. Thanks
EXCELLENT READ. Would like to believe a lawyer could have this much feeling for jusice and the truth.
Of the five books in this series, I've only read the first two.  This book was more enjoyable than the first. I didn't want to put it down.

This book has it all! I am a masters student at Columbia University studying Neuroscience and Education. My thesis is on the neuroscience of mindfulness and I have read over 20 books touting mindfulness research in an educational setting - So many of them are for beginners seem to be written for an ideal classroom that does not exist (did I mention that I'm an 8th grade Special Education teacher in Brooklyn?) This book is full of the newest research and applications for the classroom. It hits on interdisciplinary levels, such as social emotional learning, and the fixed/growth mindset. This book would be great to give anyone you know who has developed learned helplessness or chronic stress over time - regardless of whether they are an educator or student. Aside from this book, I also recommend Daniel Rechtschaffen's book, The Way of Mindful Education, which has great lesson plans for students of all ages (and all demographics) in the classroom.

Mindfulness is the capacity to achieve nonjudgmental awareness of experiences in the present moment, without grasping or aversion. (Boddhi, 1999).  Research has revealed that there are specific identifiable components of mindfulness meditation: attention regulation; body awareness; emotion regulation; and change in perspective on the self.  (Holzel, et al., 2011, p. 539)

There is currently a great renewal of interest in promoting Social Emotional Learning (“SEL”) in our schools, together with recognition that mindfulness based approaches could form an important component of approaches geared towards development of social-emotional skills.  Research shows that we have a greater need than ever for schools to address the nonacademic needs of students, as statistically significant minorities of school aged children have statistically significant emotional/behavioral vulnerabilities and lack of academic readiness.  (Jennings P., Lantieri, L, & Roeser, R., 2012, p. 372).  There are two main avenues through which this can be accomplished:  (1) creating a curriculum that promotes mindfulness (and SEL) through inquiry-based, collaborative, experiential learning (as already done in certain private schools, e.g., Montessori and Reggio Emilia); and (2) instructing teachers and students in the regular use of mindfulness based practices, preferably as part of an organization-wide or state-wide SEL program.

Against this backdrop, a number of books have been published in recent years, exploring ways in which mindfulness can be used to support the work of education in the social-emotional arena.  One such book is Mindful Learning, written by two professors at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia, Drs. Craig Hassed and Richard Chambers.  This book would be an excellent first read for educators who would like to learn about the science behind, and benefits of, mindfulness practices.  The book is scaffolded in a way that allows for clear understanding of the potential positive relationship between mindfulness and the mental qualities necessary for efficient learning.  The reach of the book is broad, ranging from the science supporting the use of mindfulness based interventions, to the mental skill sets needed for effective learning, to actual practices that educators may use to develop a mindfulness practice.

Unsurprisingly, given the secular focus of the book, the authors focus on four cognitive aspects of mindfulness: Perception; Nonattachment (letting go); Acceptance; and Present moment (awareness). (Id., pp. 12-17):

• Perception:  lack of perception involves believing the stories our brains tell us, having a narrow viewpoint or a fixed mindset;  with mindfulness we may begin perceiving what we project onto situations, for example, bringing us to a different perspective, seeing the bigger picture or seeing things from a different angle.
• Nonattachment: involves letting go of or releasing thoughts, feelings, ideas; neither grasping onto or pushing away from (aversion).

• Acceptance:  after noticing or acknowledging what is (perception) and being neutral towards it (non-attachment), can we accept or allow things to be as they are? The authors offer a caveat: “(u)sing acceptance to make something go away is actually nonacceptance masquerading as acceptance…”  What is helpful here is remembering the impermanence of all things, that this too shall pass. Also, we should refrain from “shooting the second arrow”, that is, letting go of any judgment of the thought, idea, feeling, or sensation as “bad” or “wrong”.  Although this may sound, it is not easy – because sometimes what arises is difficult or painful or even intolerable.  (Id., p. 16).
• Present Moment: “The present moment is the only moment that has any legitimate claim to reality.  The past and future are just ideas.  The past and future never actually exist…” (Id., p. 17).

At the beginning of Mindful Learning, the authors discuss the need for a pedagogical shift to an inquiry based approach to education, i.e., the dialectic approach, as opposed to the traditional public school approach where the teachers are providing knowledge and the student absorbs it (without much reflection or personal connection).  There is recognition of the importance that students maintain a childlike fascination with the subject matter.  The question is posed, how do we keep children interested, and not destroy their naturally inquisitive spirit, ending up like a “snuffed out candle”? (Hassed & Chambers, 2015, p. 3, quoting Einstein).

“Einstein felt that real discovery was an intuitive process.  Intuition…comes from the Latin word intueri, meaning “to look upon, consider, contemplate.”  It is not “an unconscious, unreflecting, conditioned, or automatic way of seeing things.  It is all about being conscious and aware.  If we really look we have a chance of understanding, because what is within us is connecting with what we are observing.  Thus connectedness, or unity, goes hand in hand with learning mindfully.”  (Ibid.).

After this beginning, there is very little in the book that discusses changing the pedagogy of schools; rather the primary focus is on educating teachers so that they may be mindful models of educational leadership in the classroom.  Developing mindfulness in teachers is viewed as an issue of primary importance  by the authors: “Education (on mindfulness) needs to take place at a number of levels, starting with the training of quality mindfulness teachers.” (Hassed & Chambers, 2015, p. 179).  Thus, Mindful Learning focuses to a large extent on bringing mindfulness into the classroom through teachers who have developed their own mindfulness practices, as well as through scripted mindfulness exercises to be practiced with students, which may be found in Chapter 20.

Much of the book is devoted to presenting evidence of why engaging in mindfulness is a beneficial practice for teachers and students.  However,  they do recognize the indispensable truth that “(m)indfulness can only be offered; the choice is always the person’s own as to whether they will take up the gift.” (Id., p. 145).  “Mindfulness cannot be imposed on students.  They will need a level of motivation and insight in order to engage with the process.  Otherwise they will just pretend to go through the motions to keep the teacher happy, or – even worse – they will build up resistance and resentment to mindfulness, an attitude that might be difficult to shift.” (p. 144).

The authors call for a type of “applied mindfulness” which departs from traditional mindfulness practice by its results driven focus of attaining specific goals, such as stress reduction and performance enhancement.  In contrast, mindfulness as developed from ancient Buddhist philosophy has at its core the purpose of achieving enduring happiness and gaining insight into the true nature of existence (impermanent, unreliable, and non-self). (Boddhi, 1999).  The authors state that, instead of teaching mindfulness and “letting students figure out on their own how to apply it,” they teach mindfulness with the stated goals of managing stress, improving study performance (by learning to sustain attention and focus over a period of time), developing presence of mind rather than trying to multitask , and overcoming procrastination. (Hassed & Chambers, 2015, p. 48).

The definition of mindfulness in Mindful Learning is a “mental discipline aimed at training attention” (Id., p. 6).  In this reader’s opinion, this definition omits the true purpose of mindfulness as a path for transformation, that involves development of wisdom, intuition and discernment, liberation from suffering, and inner growth of loving-kindness, compassion, sympathetic joy, and equanimity (the brahmaviharas). The concern here is that mindfulness could end up becoming a tool to enable students to be calm and compliant with a dull curriculum, rather than following a path paved with curiosity and kindness, with an aim of inner transformation.

Drs. Hassed and Chambers believe that applied mindfulness is justified by the results:  that hooking students and teachers into trying mindfulness (as a secular practice that enhances performance and reduces stress) will allow them to experience mindfulness.  The viewpoint is that once people begin practicing mindfulness, they will understand on an experiential level the benefits of such a practice, and then begin to apply it more broadly in their lives, that is, generalize mindfulness to other areas of their lives.  The concept of “applied mindfulness” will likely appeal to many within the public education system, with its focus on measurable results in attainment of educational skills.  However, this view of mindfulness arguably omits the heart of mindfulness:  which is to wake up to whatever is, in the present moment, and to allow what is there to just be, with loving-kindness and gentle curiosity.  A question that arises is, if the practice of “applied mindfulness” is results-driven and goal-oriented, is it still mindfulness?

However, it is understood that our public education system is mandated, to the extent possible, to use secular methodologies shown to be effective by scientific research which will enable students to make measurable progress in skill acquisition.  Perhaps what we need are some additional goals in education, which incorporate skills which are not so measurable, such as kindness, empathy, and joy in learning?  Our society is so results driven, can we allow space for these priceless capacities to arise?

Putting aside the issue of “applied mindfulness,” there are many positive aspects to this book.  For instance, the discussion of mindfulness and attention in the early part of the book is spot on.  The authors discuss how we are often not even aware of where our attention is, and that noticing what our attention is focused upon is the first step in developing mindfulness.  “Mindfulness is not a distraction from our worries.”  (Hassed & Chambers, 2015, p. 9).  “Mindfulness meditation is…not a method of tuning out but rather of tuning in…..” (Id., p. 11).  “We cannot stop the mind from thinking” . . . . . but we can “learn to be less reactive to it or involved in it.” (Id., p. 10).

One of the main thrusts of this book is the positive impact of mindfulness upon executive functioning skills, which are high level functions of the brain’s prefrontal cortex important for learning.  “Research shows that practicing mindfulness activates many of the same brain areas as those that are active when we are engaged in executive functioning…….particularly attention, short-term memory, regulating emotional impulses, planning, and mental flexibility.”  (Id., p. 24).  Strengthening these capacities is one of the primary purposes for the use of “applied mindfulness” according to the authors.
One of the ways in which the authors explain the benefits of mindfulness is by exploring the “costs” of mindlessness, including the following:
• Wasting Time
• Not Understanding Things
• Mental Roadblocks
• Poor Emotional Well-Being
• Not Enjoying Life
• Can’t Sleep
• Communicating Poorly
• More Distractible
• Lack of Motivation
• Poor Memory
• Effects on the Brain (Id., pp. 40-45).

We are reminded of an important lesson from neuroscience: that whatever we practice becomes the habit of the mind.  “(W)e give power to whatever our attention is directed to.”  (Id., p. 11).  As  Dr. Dan Siegel often says, “neurons that fire together, wire together”.  Thus, the more we practice “unmindfulness”, the more we will reap the “costs” listed above.  Research has shown that mindfulness can “ literally shape our brain in ways that make it much easier to concentrate, remember and learn, regulate emotions and behaviors, reason and think abstractly.” (Id., p. 32).

In furtherance of cultivating mindfulness within the teaching environment, the authors suggest creating a mindful physical environment, regular practices of self-care, and a teaching style that is calm and enthusiastic, encouraging openness, and which uses mindfulness practices in the classroom.  The authors do recognize the importance of teaching mindfulness not as “a separate skill divorced from other aspects of the curriculum” but rather as something that is “integrated with other content.” (Id., p. 141).  There appears to be an assumption that teachers will intuitively know how to do such things as a result of their own mindfulness practices, as the authors do not deeply delve into how these things might be accomplished as a practical matter.
However, this may be because one of the key points made by the authors is the importance of learning from failure.  They state that “(a) mindful response to failure is:
• To be able to sit with, and be open to, the discomfort.
• To acknowledge the failure, turn the attention to it rather than avoid it, learn from it, and then move on.
• To take a bigger view of life with its ups and downs (this too will pass).
• Not to measure our self-worth by one apparent success or failure in one particular episode of life.”  (p. 89).
So if teachers are mindful of failure, they will in fact be integrating mindfulness into the curriculum, by learning from their own experiences..
A large part of this book is devoted to motivating teachers and parents to develop a regular practice of mindfulness, as well as to be self-aware of:
• teaching style (including whether process or product oriented; and fixed or growth mindset),
• levels of stress,
• levels of emotional well-being and enjoyment of life,
•  personal bias,
•  level of mental flexibility,
• problem solving skills,
• level of resilience,
• work practices (procrastination, disorganization, lack of perspective, multitasking, unrealistic expectations vs. hopeful aspirations), and
• complacency.

The authors believe that if mindfulness practices are adopted first by adults, this will result in mindful teaching methods, as a result of changing expectations into aspirations, changing mindsets, learning to learn from failure, and working with emotions mindfully.  Thankfully, the authors do fully recognize that such change does not happen overnight. (Id., p. 167).
Conclusion:

Mindful Learning covers a large range of territory, and has sufficient depth for an educator’s first introduction to Mindfulness.  The book is carefully written to avoid any religious, philosophical, or spiritual overtones, which might cause discomfort in the educational setting. The focus on the brain-based (or cognitive) aspects of mindfulness (e.g., improving executive functioning skills such as attention and working memory) give the book a solid grounding in educational science.  The practices included in the back of the book are well scripted, and useful.  While the book does not discuss needed changes in state-wide or school district-wide pedagogy to bring mindfulness into the mainstream of education, it does address some of the challenges associated with organizational change.

One concern that arose is the potential effect of divorcing of mindfulness from grounding in ethics (such as the Noble Eightfold Path), loving-kindness, ethical/moral values, or spiritual principles.  This book contains William James’ oft-quoted statement on “the importance of being able to focus attention as the ultimate education.” (Id., p. 5).  However, mindfulness is not just about the focusing of attention, but also about the attitude that we cultivate towards what we pay attention to, and how we act in response to what arises.

While this book has omitted what many consider to be the true purposes of mindfulness: a path for transformation, liberation from suffering, wisdom, development of kindness, compassion, sympathetic joy and equanimity (the brahmaviharas), that may well have been intentional, in order to make delivery of the message of mindfulness more palatable to those within the educational system.

It is encouraging that books such as Mindful Learning have arrived on the educational scene, which are helping to breathe new life into the movement to bring mindfulness-based approaches, which are consistent with social-emotional learning principles, into the realm of public education.
About the Author:

Carla C. Leone, Esq., is an attorney in private practice, who represents the civil rights of children with neurodiversity.  She holds a professional certificate in Autism Spectrum Disorders from Lesley University’s Graduate School of Education, and is currently working towards a Master’s degree in Mindfulness at Lesley University’s Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

It had been only a few days since the end of the school year.  I stared down at the book titled Mindful Learning, written by Dr. Craig Hassed and Dr. Richard Chambers, mindfulness consultants at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia.  The cover, which looks like a chalkboard, triggered a flood of memories from the classroom.  Was I ready to read my first full-fledged mindfulness in education book for the summer?

After a week or two of mindful waiting, I started reading, not knowing exactly what to expect.  I had chosen to read this book because it has been marketed toward people who work with high-school age children and above.  Other related books - “The Way of Mindful Education”, “Teach, Breathe, Learn”, and “Mindfulness for Teachers” – I read while teaching middle school.  Now that I had moved onto teaching older students, it seemed appropriate to explore a resource targeting this age group.

True to the Aussie way of being, Hassed and Chambers adopt a casual tone, even when delving into complex topics such as neuroscience.  Throughout the book, they use the pronouns “we” and “us”, referring to the wider community as well as to themselves.  They also use brevity to their benefit, using the least possible words that still relay their thoughts. But blink and you might miss a transition, giving a feeling of abrupt turns.  Look closely and you’ll see how carefully they organized their book.  They begin by defining education and mindfulness before moving on to exploring mindfulness in student learning, which is the text’s main focus.  They then discuss mindfulness in creativity, sports, and relationships.  Later, the authors apply mindfulness to teachers, even laying out ways to work with those resistant to incorporating these practices into the classroom.  They follow by describing how mindfulness goes well beyond school walls.  For concluding thoughts, they briefly mention potential approaches that organizations can implement when incorporating mindfulness, along with common snafus they may face.  For takeaway tools, they include twelve sample exercises for teachers to try in or out of the classroom.

Instead of beginning with a definition of mindfulness, Hassed and Chambers first invite us to pause by asking the question, “What is education?”  It has taken me years to fully arrive at their view of education as a holistic endeavor where teachers and students can learn from any situation – an endeavor where teachers facilitate or elicit existing insight through inquiry and questioning.  Mindfulness supports this perspective.  I read about this holistic approach while in graduate school for teaching and learning, but I didn’t understand or embody it until I went so fully away from this view and back again after almost leaving the profession entirely.  Why is it that so many teachers lose sight of teaching as drawing out from within?  I still grapple with this question, trying to balance my own views with the existing structures in the public school district where I teach.  From this searching perspective, I fully appreciated the authors’ note - “The journey to becoming a mindful teacher and learner is a lifelong project” (2014, p.4).

In our fast-paced world, mindfulness can appear counter-intuitive.  Instead of pausing to navel gaze, shouldn’t we be doing more to get ahead?  Hassed and Chambers efficiently and thoroughly address the misconception that mindfulness meditation is about stopping and clearing one’s thoughts.  They explain how it is more of a process of awareness and release from the grips of thinking, giving away our attachments to our thoughts.  They don’t contribute anything new to the existing foundational knowledge of mindfulness.  Rather, they organize information into a secular, digest-able fashion, using vignettes from the school setting.  Then, to boost our confidence and conviction about the importance of mindfulness in a world of skepticism, they ground us in the dominant language of science.  Explaining clearly how mindfulness practices can shape our brains to improve concentration, memorization, emotional regulation, reasoning, and abstract thinking, they convince even a skeptic to explore the potential of mindfulness to enhance (and even transform) our educational, recreational, and personal lives.

Hassed and Chambers’ find a niche in their attention to the effects of mindfulness on stress, focus, and performance in older students.  Like many others, I used to think that we need a certain bit of stress in order to perform better.  However, the authors illustrate how we can perform from a mindful state of calm and confidence, free from stress.  It’s worth looking up the Hassed mindfulness-based stress-performance graph to rethink your view on stress.  They convinced me that mindfulness is a valuable skill, mindset, and way of being that helps us reduce stress and enhance attention.  If you aren’t convinced by their graph, read their chapter on why attention matters – the costs of unmindfulness.  Wasting time, not understanding things, poor emotional well-being, and not enjoying life are just some of the outcomes of living in the dark.

What struck me about Hassed and Chambers is how intentional they are with their use of mindfulness in education.  Instead of leaving the effects of mindfulness on student learning up to chance, they have specifically created a program, Mindfulness for Academic Success (MAS), to apply mindfulness to studying.  This program came out of their personal realizations that people more easily comprehend mindfulness when the focus is more explicit.  They share a few exercises to give us a taste of MAS.  I tried out their study meditation where students work on a written task while noting any mental distractions on one side of the paper.  Experientially, I understood their intention of helping students fully acknowledge and accept distractions in order to fully let go of them.  This was my first encounter with a program focused so directly on academic behavior – I wish I had enrolled in this program as an overwhelmed undergraduate.

Their chapters on resilience, emotional development, and communication sometimes read like a self-help book, providing tips and explanations on how to practice mindfulness to promote these skills.  Although this tone can be perceived as superficial, it can also be construed as actually helpful in providing us with a broader view of what mindfulness can do for our students.  Hassed and Chambers even take the time to address creativity, movement, and relationships since school is not always just about academics; arts, athletics, and social events play a large part in many communities.  In addition, I found their chapter on eMindfulness – how paying attention helps us use media more wisely – timely and highly applicable for our ultra-connected young adults.

I particularly enjoyed their roadmap for building mindfulness practices in children throughout the years, so that they do not fall into “mindfulness fatigue”.  Hassed and Chambers begin with Elementary School – Years 1-3: “simple mindfulness exercises to provide some quiet at the start and end of class” and end with College or University: “Teach how mindfulness applies to leadership, professional development, higher executive functioning, and self-care” (2014, p.142-143).  It is powerful to envision what mindfulness can look like if woven into long-term educational planning.  Of course, this roadmap is only an example of what can happen, as educators very well know the intricate complexities of planning and implementing curricula in large educational systems.

Lest you think Hassed and Chambers focus only on students, fear not.  They thoughtfully round out their mindfulness tour with a focus on the teacher.  As someone who has experienced almost all of the major barriers to teaching – burnout, stress, poor mental health, to name a few – it was cathartic to have someone put these difficulties into words and how mindfulness can help us to work through or around these so-called barriers.

Just when you get the sense that something might be missing from their whole tour, Hassed and Chambers admit that the attention training aspect of mindfulness can seem a little cold by itself.  They broaden mindfulness beyond the classroom by noting how mindfulness can be equally thought of as heartfulness.  They write, “The word mindfulness implies ‘mind’ – which many people equate to the brain – and so risks obscuring what is most important about learning to be more awake, open, and loving in each moment of life” (2014, p. 162).  As I arrived at the end of the book, I sensed some warm and fuzzies, fully opening to the potential of mindfulness to transform our way of being in the world.

Overall, I am filled with gratitude toward Hassed and Chambers for providing teachers, administrators, and parents with some clarity in our lifelong journeys to becoming mindful people and role models for our children.  I envision Mindful Learning as a useful resource for a school district or university interested in implementing mindfulness.  The text probably will appeal more-so to teachers of older students who are expected to study independently and become more aware of their learning habits, but the principles apply to every age level.  For a school district, it would be a great way for teachers to become more well-versed in what mindfulness actually is and how it can help.  The chapters can be used as stand-alone resources over a longer period of time, leaving plenty of room for discussion and dialogue.  After all, it is up to individuals and small groups to decide what to do with this valuable information.

Keep in mind as you continue your exploration of mindfulness in education that there is a multitude of resources to drawn from.  To learn more about the unmindfulness, or mindlessness, check out Ellen Langer’s "Mindfulness" (1990).  Interested in the neurobiology of mindfulness?  Read Willoughby Britton and Arielle Sydnor’s “Neurobiological models of meditation practices: Implications for application with youth” (2015) in Chris Willard and Amy Saltzman’s “Teaching Mindfulness Skills to Kids and Teens”.  Amishi Jha also delves into the science behind mindfulness in her talk, “Improving Attention and Working Memory” (2012), which can be found on Vimeo.  Searching for more guided mindfulness meditation practice?  Try the Headspace app, which leads you through a 30-day foundational practice before opening up to different themes such as health, relationships, or performance.  The first ten days are free, so don’t hesitate!  May your journey be filled with insights, connections, and personal growth.
There is so much fascinating information in here about how the brain works, plus how we can best help our students learn.  I highly recommend it!
Clear, concise, well-supported. Very helpful to anyone hoping to gain an overview of well-documented aspects of mindfulness and the brain!
Dry book. Interesting material, but it's a chore to read. This may be because I had to read it for a class. Take it with a grain of salt.
Excellent book on Mindfulness .. well written with lots of good ideas //recommended
Excellent

This book provides the reader with an A - Z understanding of mindful learning.  What became clear to me in reading this book is that mindful learning is not just for the classroom, but for the curriculum of life. If you value learning this book if for you.  Well written, well researched and practical.
This book is made for me. I lived many years as absent mind person, now this book is helping to overcome that and I am enjoying my life.

I am an avid reader, approximately 100 books per year on a variety of topics and themes.  I have to say that The Dark Tower I: The Gunslinger is one of the most unreadable books I have ever encountered.  I powered through over half of the book before I asked myself;  WTH am I spending my time reading this nonsense.  I will never attempt to finish this book due to the intense boredom of it.  I can't say more than that except don't waste your time.
I don't understand the fascination with this series, much less Stephen King.  Most of his books end up with an alien monster.  This one ended up in the trash.

Stephen King says he started his epic series, THE DARK TOWER, when he was a very young man. Perhaps with the arrogance and/or enthusiasm of youth this series is a mash-up of any number of literary traditions. In most hands it could have wound up a mess.
THE GUNSLINGER, the first in the series, opens, appropriately enough, with “the gunslinger” chasing an unidentified man across a nameless desert:
“The man in black fled across the desert, and the gunslinger followed.”
The scene has the look and feel of an old spaghetti western, which King freely admits:
“… I realized that what I wanted to write was a novel that contained Tolkien’s sense of quest and magic but set against Leone’s almost absurdly majestic Western backdrop.”
I think he succeeded:

“The desert was the apotheosis of all deserts, huge, standing to the sky for what looked like eternity in all directions. It was white and blinding and waterless and without feature save for the faint, cloudy haze of the mountains which sketched themselves on the horizon and the devil-grass which brought sweet dreams, nightmares, death. An occasional tombstone sign pointed the way…”

The Gunslinger (eventually we learn is name is Roland – an epic/mythic/heroic name) comes across a mysterious young man who has somehow been transported from (our) contemporary New York to this strange land. No attempt is made at explanation.

When Roland comes to a town, we learn that this is post-apocalyptic time in which the world as we know it has been destroyed, possibly though nuclear war. It is a dystopian vision that predates the current popularity of such stories.

As the journey continues, old-fashioned magic becomes part of the mix. Also a bit of derring do in the style of Indiana Jones. Also some fantasy in the vein of George R. R. Martin’s “Game of Thrones” (“Winter is coming.”)
And, of course, questions of good versus evil are explored.
Whew.

Any type of cross-genre mixing is difficult to do well, much less on an epic scale. I have not even looked at subsequent books in the series in the hopes of being continually surprised when I do read them. I expect this volume is a good launch. If anybody could make it a success it would in the hands of Stephen King.
Confusion and Unmoored Sufferings

While reading this book, it almost seemed like the author was creating confusion and misery for misery and confusion’s sake!  Why would you do that in the first book of a series?  If Stephen King’s name wasn’t on this book, I sincerely doubt most readers would have finished reading it.  That said after completing the book I googled it and found King’s fans encouraging people to “power” through the book because book two is good, while on the same page I found others talking about underage sex that is weird in further editions of the series.  This leads me to one question:

“Why did you create such frivolous misery in your novel Mr. King?”  Apart from Jake, it just seems like pain that neither builds the character, nor furthers the story.  It is, to me, uninteresting and does nothing but sear and jade your reader’s imagination.

This book was much less interesting than some less known/self-published smaller authors today like AC Cobble, Peter Flannery, A.G. Riddle and others.  In fact this being the first Stephen King book I’ve ever read, I was left wondering if the only reason he has been so popular was due to the advertisements of his brand over the years.  After all, prior to Amazon a writer could not easily get their works known or published.  I now wonder if King is really deserving of his lofty place amongst well known literary authors.

The final quarter of this book from the flashback of Roland’s “coming of age” through the cave onward was decent and even good occasionally, but prior to that I wanted to stop reading the book several times.

Maybe my review is unfair, but this doesn’t seem like a work worthy of one of the past century’s most popular authors.  Read it if you must, or just read the cliff’s notes version and save yourself some pointless misery.

There are many Stephen King books that I really enjoy (Salems Lot, Finders Keepers, The Stand, 11/22/63 just to name a few . . . in fact, 11/22/63 is one of my all-time favorite books).  As such, I really had high hopes for The Gunslinger.  However, the story line was disjointed, confusing, and not very enjoyable at all.  I kept expecting the flow of the book to smooth-out and become a "cannot put down" read.  However, this never occurred.  In the end, I was completely disappointed.  I have heard that other Dark Tower books are much better, but I disliked The Gunslinger so much that I'm not sure I'll read any others.
Once one of my all time favorite books.

Stephen King revised this book and it is TERRIBLE!!!  You get no back story and don’t know who some of the characters are, how they played a roll in Roland’s life, what he went through to get to where he is now. NOTHING!!!  It is terrible!!

In terms of story, this is easily the best volume in the series so far. The characters and setting have so much depth, and we learn much about who they all are and why they've been thrust together on this ongoing, epic journey.

And this story FEELS epic, too, as Roland and his band of unlikely heroes traverse miles and miles from the first page to the last. The setting and descriptions are all wonderful - you can see, hear, and smell everything the characters are... for good or ill, because some of the places the characters find themselves in are pretty bleak, to say the least.

The only problem is that it ends on a cliffhanger. Which ordinarily, would be cause for an immediate one-star review from me, and a solemn vow to never read another book in the series. But because this is Stephen King, and because I've been mostly happy with the series so far, I'm going to press on and give it another shot.

Then, the Kindle Edition I read is riddled with typos. Most of these are probably OCR issuess from scanning a print edition of this book, but it just smacks of plain laziness on the part of the publisher. I've reported them all as "Quality Issues" on Amazon.

I know these are supposed to be the great Stephen King epic, but after three books and NOTHING happening I give up. I don't even care about the characters and he has spent 3 books developing them. He is constantly making references to the pop culture of the 1980s so I,m guessing in 10 years or so no one will know what he's talking about. There are better books to read I'm done.
Roland went for a walk in the desert.  He had a mule with no name.  Did he feel good to get out of the rain?  I can't remember  ...  the palaver left me too numb to care for his pain.
This might be a useful introduction to an epic series,  but the story does not stand in its own.

Reading this series again, after King finally concluded it - and though it's been over a decade since my first reading of the gunslinger's ka-tet, it's like my old friends have been waiting for my return. In this slice of the tale, the other characters start coming into their own and King draws his characters a deeper hue, layering meaning and darkening shadows.

It's a tense ride, a fulfilling adventure and page-turner that starts to eat away at your sleeping hours. Be warned, I think these pages are laced with some addictive substance...maybe Eddie's been at it again. I can't stop reading this series.

As the SF Opera was featuring an adaptation, I decided to read the Kindle so-called "abridged" version of this classic. While the beautiful writing depicts the intricacies and dynamics of that era, the constant repetition became boring. Nevertheless, I persevered till thankfully the end. Thank goodness for Kindle as the archaic writing style allowed me to look up words on practically every page.
Be advised, due to type font it's 3 times as long as regular Kindle books of this size. It take's between 1 and 2 hours to read a chapter and there are 56 of them!
Children's book rather than the authentic, adult version classic. Buyer be ware!
Bad translation. I have heard great things about this story but could not get past the poor translation.
Reminds me of Jane Austin. Interesting peak into Chinese society. Well Ming era anyway.The 2nd book maybe better, I hope.
This is a tough read. It is apparently a well known book in China, but in translation it is nearly incomprehensible.
translation too direct very Asian style of construction and words used
The Hawkes translation
is probably the most enjoyable for English readers, though in some ways it is maybe over-adapted.  The Yang translation
is more literal.  This Joly translation is the most literal and even contains some explicit parenthetic explanations of various Chinese terms.  It is awkwardly literal sometimes.
Few readers will be in this position: but if you want an English translation to help you with the Chinese original this is probably the best.  Yang is just about as helpful.

Joly's was the first substantial translation of the classic Chinese novel "Dream of the Red Chamber", now reissued by Tuttle, lightly revised (or so it seems). However - and this is a big however - while the translation is relatively free from major errors, it has a nauseatingly crabbed and archaic style which makes understanding a near-impossibility. The thous and whithers and whenceforths are not excised from this text. Now that we have the David Hawkes/John Minford Penguin translation and the Yangs' more literal version, Joly's version can safely be binned. If you are curious about this version, Joly's 56 chapters are all available at the Gutenberg website.

Truth in advertising should, I believe, dictate that potential buyers be aware of two issues with this book:  First, the book may have been recently published, but the translation goes back to two turns of the century ago.  That's not a bad thing, but the buyer should know that this is not even close to a recent translation.  Second, this book is not the whole book.  It actually contains less than half of "The Dream of the Red Chamber," and abruptly breaks off leaving the reader suspended with nowhere to go.  That's not necessarily bad either if only we were told that this was the case, but we are not.  If you want the whole story, this is not the book for you.

What an exceptional little book. It is apparently a 'Real Reads' series, which I had not previously heard of. The website ([...] states the books are "retellings of great literature from around the world, each fitted into a 64-page book." The books themselves are paperback (I see they also are available on Audible), but what a lovely paperback, with a book cover, thick, thick paper and charming illustrations. Other features that I enjoyed were a list of characters (which I did use quite often) and in the back, there is a 'Taking Things Further' section. This section expands on the original book, followed by a section of questions and such, that one could use for a book club or more in-depth study. Also included here is a mid-nineteenth century illustraction by Chinese artist Sun Wen. What a lovely book to introduce young readers to great liturature.

It is timeless Chinese storytelling, with all the haunting beauty, drama and heartache. This may be a bit of a challange for younger readers as there are instances of suicide, domestic violence, drunkenness, murder and adultry. These displays of behavior are not detailed and if one is old enough to read Shakespeare, then this book would also be appropriate, I imagine.

I am ashamed to admit, I have not read the original which is one of China's four great classic novels. I therefore cannot say how well this abridged copy captures the 2000 or so page original. What I can state, is that this shortened story is still beautiful, detailed and sadly haunting. It is probably one of those books that every learned child should read. It gives insight to Chinese history and culture in a compact but entertaining dose. It piqued my interest enough that I put the unabridged english version on my 'to read' list. I would have loved this in junior high after we read Romeo and Juliet. It would have been a interesting comparison in cultures.
Disclosure: I read a free copy of the book in return for my candid review. Be assured, my opinion is honest, and I do not owe or know the author/publisher.

This review started as a comment on one of the other reviews, a negative one.  I'm going to leave it intact but it will read awkwardly.  My first Miles LP was Nefertiti which I purchased in 1968, so I've been a fan for a while.  I bought Bitches Brew way back when and probably played it once.  I kept waiting for someone to take a solo and found it boring.  I have always liked the first side of Jack Johnson, especially the beginning through the end of MIles' solo, which is probably my all time favorite solo by him.  I bought Get Up With It way back when and probably forced myself to play it once.  Who wants to hear Miles play organ?

So starting this book my collection was covered for the Bird recordings and the Prestige box with Trane, Columbia box with Trane, 60s quintet box, On the Corner, Fillmore, Birth of Cool.  Reading this made me realize the big gap between Birth of Cool and Trane.  I bought Bag's Groove especially for the two Monk cuts but I feel like I need more there, especially the Sonny Rollins sides.

Which brings me to the electric stuff and the comeback stuff.  Reading the book got me to rebuy Bitches Brew on CD and to relisten to On the Corner.  I have to say this book has helped me to accept those recordings on their own terms and not as letdowns from the mid 60s.  The book has also encouraged me to try a comeback album and I've ordered We Want Miles since that gets pretty positive reviews.

What got me to write and amend my original comment and then turn it into this review were all the negative comments from reviewers who slam with author for his opinions of the electric period.  I saw lots of positive comments by the author here and inclusions of positive reviews.  It is certainly not all positive but it is not nearly as negative as some would have you believe.  The thing is that many of those electric albums do not fit any definition of jazz that I am familiar with.  They are music, Black Music as Miles would say, but not really jazz.  Anyone who first met acoustic Miles would have to be disappointed when he took that direction.  Seems that some of our reviewers here started with electric Miles and they get pretty bent out of shape when you question that music, as did most of his piers way back when.  So I'm glad for this book.  I'm glad that it helped me appreciate the music I couldn't formerly get into.  What follows are my first couple of passes at a comment on a very negative review.

As I work my way through this book I get the feeling this reviewer is way more biased than the author, who he accuses of bias. Should the author set aside his opinions about what he is writing about? While I am just finishing up the first half I have seen instances where he quotes reviews that are contrary to his own for the sake of inclusiveness and objectivity. And your comments about the author's feelings about the autobiography are really nothing more than your own "fever dream".

As for the value of the autobiography, I'll follow Miles' lead. He spent most of his career trying to get people to judge only the music and not him the person. He'd turn his back or leave the stage when he wasn't playing, for instance. Miles is an interesting guy but I read this book because his music and the development of his music is what I'm interested in, not his sex life or the drugs he took.

Putting down On The Corner is sacrieligious only in the Church of Miles the God. That is just one of many crazy comments here. I haven't got to the Jack Johnson part and I'm anxious to read that. I love Jack Johnson, especially side one with my all time favorite Miles solo. But I also own the Complete Jack Johnson and I see how it was assembled from different pieces. It was not an organic performance. While there are elements of Jazz there with some great improve I'm not sure I fully call it jazz. It is music, great music, but the producer had a lot to do with the finished product.

Back in the 70s I bought a double Miles LP that basically (as I remember) consisted of him noodling on an electric keyboard. Same guy who played on Kind Of Blue and Nefertiti but way way boring. He created a lot of important work but he wasn't perfect and everything he did isn't genius.

...Update: I'm into the final couple chapters now and I have a couple impressions on the "electric' reviews. First, they aren't all entirely negative. He also cites other reviewers for concerts and LPs that may be positive. The musicians from this period get a lot of positive input. From my listening of Bitches Brew and On the Corner I think he conveys the sound and structure of these discs fairly well. There are a lot of places where there isn't much happening besides a rhythmic churn. Sometimes I like, sometimes I don't. For me the Pinnacle of Miles is the 60s quintet. I think Nefertiti was my first Miles album. I think his trumpet playing was best in that period and the conception of the music was the most advanced. We have all that earlier music to color our opinions of him. I doubt Miles would be so highly thought of if we only had the post-Jack Johnson music.

A couple disappointments: When he mentions the beginnings of "jazz rock" from the rock side he mentions the obvious pop bands like BST and Chicago, but my memory is that the first people to add horns were Paul Butterfield and Mike Bloomfield with Electric Flag. The Butterfield band when Bloomer was still there was the most musically capable group of nonjazz musicians at that time. They do a very nice job of Nat Adderley's Work Song on their second LP. That the author mentions none of this is disappointing and maybe points to a lack of first hand knowledge of that music from that period. Later Bloomfield played as a guest on a Woody Herman album.

My other disappointment was the review of Jack Johnson. Side one, especially the first half will always be my favorite electric Miles Davis. Most reviewers of this album highlight the funky guitar that starts side one by McLaughlin and the fantastic, out front solo by Miles: very declamatory and aggressive unlike much of his electric playing.
A fine book.

But Chambers is also slightly upset, I think, that Quincy Troupe got to work with Miles on his autobiography and not he -- and what Chambers' book is missing is exactly the kind of personal material (and voice) you find in Miles' autiobiograpy ("Miles").

The best thing about this book is the discussion of the wider context of Miles' music and performance ("the times"), but without Miles own voice it degenerates through the end of Part Two into a kind of annotated discography (mind you -- that's not all bad -- it is accurate and gave me a few ideas for out of the way purchases).
So, I recommend reading both this book and "Miles", for a complete picture.

Detailed history of Miles Davis's development as a jazz pioneer.  Not an easy read... but definitely informative and full of historical gems.  Worth reading for any serious Miles fans, jazz aficionados, and those interested in how art and artists influence their times.
what a great book! More insights than all the other things on Miles I've ever read. the book was in great shape, got to me quickly.
Yes, sir.

Those looking for detailed commentary on just about every Miles Davis recording session should turn to this book, while John Szwed's So What beats it on the subject of Miles' personal life.  Chambers' source material was all second-hand, for he apparently conducted no interviews himself for the project. Since the mid-80's publication of Milestones a treasure trove of new archived letters, documents, and interviews has become available from both Davis and his associates, but Chambers did an outstanding job nonetheless without it.  In fact, Miles himself borrowed, or stole if you will, from Milestones for his own autobiography to fill in the gaps in his memory of events.  At an exhaustive 800-plus pages, Milestones 1 and Milestones 2 (combined in the hefty paperback edition), really can't be beat.
I haven't read every Miles Davis bio - in particular, John Szwed's more recent book has gotten good reviews and therefore may end up replacing this one as a standard, comprehensive reference.
"Comprehensive" is probably this book's biggest asset - it tries to cover every item that Davis recorded (and released) before the mid-1980s.  Written by a non-musician, it is accessible to laymen.

Unfortunately, there are significant shortcomings.  Probably foremost is the author's bias against Davis's music from 1965 onward.  Reading his commentary on the 2nd quintet and electric eras, you get the feeling that he doesn't "get" the music and is incapable of discussing it in an insightful manner.  This is not the place to go for a substantive discussion of Sorcerer, B's Brew or Agharta.  These shortcomings also come through in his commentary of the cultural context for post-1965 recordings.

There are also numerous errors in the discographical sections.  Some of this couldn't have been avoided (when Chambers wrote the book, he didn't have the extensive online sessionographies we have today).  Other mistakes are fairly obvious to serious listeners, and make me wonder whether Chambers actually listened to the recordings he reviews.  Either way, for this information you're better off using another source.

Finally, Chambers uses no primary sources.  This is a real shame as he wrote the book when Miles and a larger number of his sidemen were alive.  His secondary sources are fairly wide-ranging, but surely we could have gotten more insight from the musicians themselves.

One aspect that was not a shortcoming to me, but may be more problematic to others, is the relatively cursory discussion of Davis's personal life.  It's discussed when necessary, but Chambers is much more interested in the music than the man.

When I picked up this book, I had maybe 15-20 Miles Davis albums and this volume piqued my interest enough to pick up many more.  In particular, his discussion of the Christmas Eve 1954 prompted me to run out and get "Miles Davis and the Modern Jazz Giants".  So if that's where you're at, go ahead and pick up this book.  If, instead, you're interested, you're interested in picking a thoughtful, thorough and accurate discussion of Davis's music, you're better off going elsewhere.

This book was a tough read for me (and apparantly for most of the reviewers before me), as I had read excerpts from it years ago and it infuriated me and interested me simultaneously. I had already read Miles' Autobiography, Ian Carr's 'The Definitive Biography' (which may not have been definitive, but was a much more level-headed, even-handed and sympathetic work than this could ever dream of being), 'So What', 'The Man With The Green Shirt' and the 'Downbeat Hall of Fame Reader' books on Miles, so I believe I already had a grasp on the man as much as anyone needs to dwell on the demons, drugs and dirt that were NOT the embodiment of this great shamanistic genius. Great artists don't ask or need to be liked or loved personally to be appreciated for their contributions to an art form, and no one in jazz made more contributions than Miles.

More a critique and discography than a true biography, this book by Chambers suffers from a virulent lack of objectivity when it covers anything from 'In a Silent Way' onwards; this probably due to the fact that it was originally written prior to the reassessment and re-release of Miles' work from 1969 onward. In the same exact way that all jazz journalists who once lauded and benighted the incomparable Tony Williams when he was a member of the Quintet later turned on him like rabid scrap yard dogs when he formed Lifetime and began the Jazz-Rock movement (it was Tony, not Miles who ushered in this new genre, truth be told - Miles gave birth to fusion, and there IS a difference), declaring him a turncoat and dismissing his entire output thereafter; the purists also reviled and detested Miles for his embracing this new music and incorporating it by going electric. The same thing happened to Dylan when he plugged in; the folkies declared him a sellout and blasphemer. To trash albums like 'On the Corner', 'Big Fun' and 'Jack Johnson' is not just short-sighted, it's downright sacrilegious. Chambers' refusal to neutrally assess these works among others, instead offering vapid opinions and utilizing/quoting other like-minded reviewers from those days to lend credence to bolster his argument make me wonder if he and Albert Goldman (who wrote the criminally disgraceful bio on John Lennon) were journalistic roommates. Biased, bitter, condescending and sometimes highly inaccurate, this book infuriated me after I decided to finally submit and read it. Tip: take your blood pressure meds before you embark on this journey.

Now that I've gotten that off my chest, I will state that this book provides a wealth of information about recording dates, historical perspectives, album dissections and probably the best overview of his output up to 'Silent Way'. If you're only going to read one book on Miles, read his autobiography. If you read two, this is also essential, though be warned that you won't really like the man himself after putting it down - it's that distorted. Add Carr's 'Definitive Bio' and 'So What' to the list and you'll really come to grips with this eternal enigma. When a giant of this stature has lived and himself created as many legends as Miles, and those who met him fabricate twice as many tales to make themselves a part of this history, the exaggerations will undoubtedly blossom corruptively into an even larger and less accurate picture that won't be very pretty. Who cares? It's the music, not the toilet-flushings that will forever be remembered. This is an important book on the most important figure in jazz, but it suffers from the resentful fever dream of a writer who cannot reconcile why he wasn't asked to co-author the autobiography instead of Quincy Troupe. (Maybe he should have been). Not that I'm enamored with Troupe either; his vacuous follow-up penned after Miles had passed, 'Miles and Me', had nothing good to state after the great man had gone; groping for substance everywhere and finding none, he resorted to making blind, completely unfounded allegations like Miles had a sexual predator relationship with Tony Williams when he was underage(WTF). Despicable comments from seemingly despicable people, bio writers are a blasphemous, bottom-feeding bunch attempting to elevate themselves while they smash the pedestals they once built for others. It's like Frank Zappa said - "Writing about music is like dancing about architecture". This may be an essential read, but not an endearing one...

Jack Chambers has done a very hard task and that is to present the life of the legendary Miles Davis to readers in a very interesting, yet complex style which was reflective of the way Miles Davis led his life and music.

Miles Davis was the premiere jazz musician of his time along with John Coltrane, Charlie "Bird" Parker, Herbie Hancock, etc, yet while you can love Davis's music, to know the man was very hard to do, since Miles Davis was a standoffish and sullen individual.  Chambers describes Davis's behavior as being sullen and hard to know because Davis's was a very shy man.  I am sure that Davis lived a tough life because of injustice, yet it is sad that he didn't trust his fans and those who cared for him.  Davis certainly lived the life of a "star", he over-indulged in sex, was an abuser of drugs, and had split personalities later on in life, yet his musical vision was almost always focused and clear, whether it be in the pinnacle of his talent (1950-1962), or his creating fusion (1967-1973), or the later part of his life.

Chambers does an excellent job of detailing the relationship Miles had with his fellow musicians such as the love-hate relationship with Theolonius Monk, the admiration and jealousy between Coltrane and Miles, as well as Miles being a mentor to such jazz greats as Herbie Hancock, John McGlaughlin, Chick Corea, etc.

I am a tremendous fan of Miles Davis jazz visions, I love his music and his musical style, yet after reading this book I feel sadness because I don't know if I pity Davis or just not liking him altogether, or admiring him no matter what, his final years were spent in paranoia, suspicion and feeding his ego, that is sad because if he would of just relaxed and enjoy his fans admiration I believe he might have lived longer.  Anyways, this is an outstanding book and is highly recommended to all jazz lovers and fans of the immortal Miles Davis.

By the time I found out about Jack Chambers' Miles biographies (two volumes, originally) they had been combined into this single book with some new material that brings the original manuscripts from the 1980's up to  date. Despite the heading on this site, this is the complete 800-odd page  monster bio, not an "introduction"!

This is a fantastic bio.  Like many other critics and older fans who were raised on jazz, Chambers  can't really relate to Miles' work from the late 1960's onwards, but he  does give it comprehensive coverage, rather than pretend that it all ended  with "The Quintet". I'm not sure that criticisms about his  quoting reviews are justified. I saw it as just being thorough - giving  details of the critics' reactions to recordings rather than just his own. I  learned much from his chronicling of events, right through to the  seventies, that I did not know.

If you are a fan of Miles' final period  (1981 comeback to his death in 1991), then you're probably the only one who  will feel short-changed. As this was not a period that interested me  greatly, I was not particularly bothered (probably exhausted by then!).
A  really professional effort.

What a beautiful book. i am happy i followed the recommendation of another reviewer who encourages to get the edition with the original writing language, not the updated lingo. At first I thought this was too laborious to read, having gotten used to reading some other devotionals that I've come to call "Fast food reads." This book is a "sit down restaurant" read, and once I settled into the idea that I wasnt going to zip through a day's entry, but that it was something to be chewed on, kind of like how cows chew cud and ruminate, lol, then I began to cherish the depth of expression in this book. I have since bought two more as gifts. A timeless collection of writings with enough hidden in it for many readings.

clear, beautiful insightful messages from multiple saints. With so many terrible devotions out there like 'Jesus calling', this and 'my utmost for his highest', remain two classic timeless devotions. They do NOT present as if Jesus was talking which is the main problem with many others. When he died He said "It is finished" When God speaks to me it is not my place to go sell that word to the world but to act on it and be obedient. What these classic devotions like Streams in the Dessert do are present insights and thoughts based on Biblical truths but not in the disguise of God's own words!

I ordered this for a friend who lost her husband. I have a paperback version in my car that I read on my lunch hour. It is very dog eared and worn and written in and underlined. In the busy work day it's wonderful to have a break and get back in the Word. There is a verse and then writing. Encouraging and filled with hope. I also sent my brother in another State a copy as he is going through tough times. It is great for all seasons of your life. It is a daily devotional and I have gone through it several years -- but each year is a little different than the prior year as far as your life circumstances.

One of my favorite features of this updated edition of Streams in the Desert are the enhancements added by the editor. The enhancements by the editor include referencing Scripture quotes and three different indexes (Contributor, Scripture, and Subject). My favorite enhancement is the subject index. This makes it easy to look up topics of interest and find relevant devotionals. While technically this book is supposed to be a "daily" devotional (one per day), I like to use it as a reference as well to jump around different sections and read whatever I happen to be interested in at the time. I believe this updated, edited edition is well worth purchasing due to the value added.

Before this book, I had only tried a devotional or two on my Bible app...could never stick with it. I heard good things about Streams In The Desert, so I decided to give it a try and I am so glad I did. I love having a physical copy to read everyday (as opposed to just reading daily devotionals from my phone) and personally love the modernized text of this edition. I use the SOAP bible study method with each entry and that really helps me to understand it. I love this devotional so much and can't wait to get some copies for my family.

I have loved this book for over thirty years and used is year after year. No matter what is going on in my life, the devotion speaks me it and lifts me up.  I got this one as a gift for a friend who has been going through very difficult problems in several areas of her life and I hoped it would be a help to her as it has been to me for so long.

The best on the market.  I receive God's direction daily, as I read from Streams In The Desert.  It is so relevant to what God is doing in my life.  This was a gift to someone that had invited me to a Bible Study, 30 years ago, when my husband had been murdered.

God brought this instrument to me 15 months ago, when I was working a Book Table at a Spiritual Renewal Retreat.  I had been called in to replace a young woman that  was unable to attend because of health reasons, at the last minute.  I know I was there by divine appointment and this was my reward.  It lifts me up at the beginning of each day.
I exhort you to buy a copy of this wonderful devotional book if you need nurturing in God's word and His purpose for your life.  Suffering is one of the prime targets and why God allows us to suffer.

One of my favorite passages from this beloved-by-many devotional tome is on the date February 4 and is about flying into the wind, to overcome its power.  The devotional ends with a little poem paraphrased from Victor Hugo: "Be like a bird that, halting in its flight, Rests on a bough too slight.  And feeling it give way beneath him sings, Knowing he hath wings."

This devotional book is well-known and has been around for decades.  It has been quoted and/or paraphrased in other publications that share spirituality through strength, hope and experience.  At first glance, the stories may seem old-fashioned and too long.  I suggest reading some of the longer pages as literature then give yourself a moment to pause.  During that important pause, you will more likely than not experience an unforgettable "Aha!" moment.

I bought this as a gift for my son and it is a lovely cover but most importantly I discovered that it is the same devotional I have had for over 20 years but in a more updated version i.e. easier to understand English. This makes an inspiring gift for anyone in your list that likes to take time to pray and meditate.  Great price as well.

I keep several of these devotional on hand at all times to give to people who are going thru rough times whether it is illness, loss or just plain hard times.  It really is the stream in the desert.  I've never read another devotional like it.  So uplifting .  Please order this.... you will be SO glad u did.  I also write excerpts from it in  cards that I send out.  Whenever you don't know what to say, just start flipping through the pages... sometimes I just copy the page or I will make a word document of a certain part in a nice font so I can just print it off and slip it into a card.

I as a pastor am reading this book to join in with several men in my congregation who are going through it. While I agree with the character qualities listed for a leader, I am struggling with the means to become that type of leader. For me, godly character comes from spending time in the presence of God, not from struggling to attain that character. Self-examination, which is good (see Psalm 139:23-24), should lead us to repentance and worship in the presence of God. It is only in the presence of the greatest good that my heart is transformed to be like Christ, which then gives me the motivation and strength to be the spiritual man I am called to be.

I grew up under a theology that stressed holiness by human effort, and it is only after suicidal guilt that I finally began to understand how God transforms us through His grace. Identity must precede activity. This book seems to lay out the correct biblical qualities of a leader, but stresses the wrong means for how to get these qualities. They are not something that can be attained apart from an intimate love relationship with the one who gives them. Spend time with Jesus. Let Him love you. Let His beauty convince you that His ways are better than the other ways of living.
A better leadership book is Crawford Loritts book, "Leadership as Identity."

In the course of reading J. Oswald Sander’s Spiritual Leadership it is fascinating that the Lord brought me to a conversation that contained the usual perception about church leadership. Earlier in the evening a gentleman had expressed interest in being a pastor and then over dinner reiterated that when talk turned to his current work. He expressed a displeasure in his current vocation and so when I asked what type of work he would like, he indicated that in reality he doesn’t like to work which is why being a pastor interested him.

Unfortunately spiritual leadership is often thought of in this way. This mindset it both saddening and maddening. It indicates a very low view of not just pastors, but all of those in leadership within the body of Christ and explains why we are content with just warm bodies rather than placing those both qualified and called into positions of leadership. Several years ago I was fortunate enough to read Spiritual Leadership for the first time and have considered it necessary reading for all believers. This month Moody Publishers is offering a redesigned of the updated version released 10 years ago. It’s worth noting that the only versions I have read have been updated and not the original, and in this latest release I see no discernible differences in the text from the 2007 update.

Originally put together as a a series of lectures, the book version is both logical and thoughtful. One cannot read the book without appreciating the effort that Sanders has put forward in conveying the material. The author delves deep into the realm of leadership addressing not just qualifications as many are so used to, although Sanders elevates these points to higher integrity than most,  but he also tackles topics such as the pastor’s ability to read, write, and communicate. The final chapters convey the necessity of building up other leaders. Therefore, despite the shortness of the chapters, the material requires time to read because of the need to be both reflective on it and convicted by it. While deep, the points are cleanly made and the path of reading is done in a logical and sequential order so that readers can ponder all aspects of leadership from beginning to end. Therefore, readers can expect the initial chapters to cover qualifications of leadership, who should be a leader, and some basic insights for becoming a leader, while the rest of the book continues to cover the process of leading itself to the eventual stepping aside from leadership and training up others to continue the work.

J. Oswald Sanders discussion points can be considered the ABC’s of leadership in that they are (a) advanced, (b) balance, and (c) comprehensive. Sanders conclusions about leadership are advanced beyond basic thinking. Instead, he challenges both modern notions about leadership and conveys just how much is involved in leading God’s people God’s way. Additionally, the author presents many aspects with a very balanced way, avoiding the pitfalls of going to one extreme or the other. For example in discussing essential qualities of leadership he tackles the topic of anger in such a way that shows its necessity, but cautious about unloving anger. Finally, Sanders is comprehensive, covering many topics that are easy to overlook like those mentioned earlier about abilities to read and write or spiritual qualities such as prayer. He also looks at areas that many are prone to put off or avoid, like disqualification, replacing leaders, and training up new ones. Such details combined with an emphasis on biblical authority makes Sanders book an easy recommendation.

Perhaps my one complaint is not with Sanders’ teaching at all, but rather with the additions that the publisher and editors have chosen to put further. The updated edition includes questions for discussion, which generally are very appreciative because they stimulate thinking and application. However, the questions are often asked in such a way that suggests that all believers are called to spiritual leadership and seem to ignore whether or not that person has been called to such a position. To be clear, Sanders nowhere advocates this. I have never had access to the first release and so lament my inability to comment upon the editor’s updates and faithfulness to Sanders’ intentions in the original publication.

One thing is certain: Sanders has a high regard for spiritual leadership as God’s work. Therefore, he conveys the seriousness with which it must be undertaken. It comes with great costs of energy, patience, pride, and so much more, and the author is certain to convey that to readers so that they understand the importance of spiritual leadership. Because he does this, the book is beneficial for all persons within the body of Christ and not just leaders (or potential leaders). It is a timeless book that has the propensity to be used by God to transform his church if people would invest the time to read it.

Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher at no cost to me for the purpose of review. However, my review was not influenced in anyway by outside sources and instead is the result of my own response to the reading of the book (in fact, I did a review of this book several years ago also highly recommending it and my opinion of it has not changed since).
This is great book filled with inspirational words of wisdom.

Sanders discussions about leadership are advanced beyond basic thinking. He conveys just how much is involved in leading God’s people God’s way. While deep, Sanders’s made is points cleanly and his topics structured in a pleasant sequential and logical order, so that readers can contemplate all aspects of leadership..

Sanders has a high regard for spiritual leadership as God’s work and he expresses the seriousness with which it must be undertaken. This makes the book beneficial for all persons within the body of Christ and not just leaders or potential leaders. Thus, I would highly recommend this book to all believers, but a must read for all leaders and aspiring leaders.  It is a timeless book that has the propensity to be used by God to transform his church if we would read and apply it’s principles.

Spiritual Leadership showed me a different style of leadership than I learned in the Army and in business. This is about dealing with God on a spiritual level and relying on Biblical principles to do God's will. It's relying less on your own abilities and relying on God. Jeffrey W. Bennett author of

This book was required reading for a Leadership class that I had to take. I am so thankful that it was. Spiritual Leadership is one of the best books ever written on Christian leadership. This book is a timeless classic in teaching the principles of leadership. Spiritual Leadership was written from two series of dynamic messages delivered to Christian Leaders overseas in 1964 and 1966. This is not a how to book; but a book that emphasizes walking in character, integrity, humility, and obedience to the Word of God.

I really enjoyed reading this book. I plan to continually read this book through out the years to come. It is an excellent guide for any one who is considering becoming a leader. It is spiritually accurate. I wish someone had place this book in my hands or at least told me about this book twenty-five years ago. It would have saved a lot of heartache and unnecessary anxiety on my part.

Spiritual Leadership will help educate you on what it takes to be a leader for God. It will help anyone build a foundation to stand upon in any position of leadership in or out of church.  It teaches you how God honors, protects and vindicates those whom he has chosen as His leaders.
Encourager Linda Flagg, LM, CS
Christian Life Coach

Great read for leaders of large and small groups. Also great read as a member of the congregation in what to look out for or how we can encourage the qualities and methods Sanders speak about in terms of leadership in our churches or study groups.
Here is a classic but a very solid classic. I enjoyed taking a few teams through this book and actually am making this one of the required readings in our Church Leadership Pipeline.
A few chapters in this book will get you to examining your own leadership and challenge you in how well you are really doing.
This is a must read!

Sanders’ book is a challenging and exhaustive reference for any believer who aspires to leadership.  It is a difficult read because its pages are packed with concise and critical words of wisdom, and each requires analysis and application to one’s own life.  At the same time, it sets the bar very high for spiritual leaders and calls each of us to another level of achievement.  True spiritual leadership is a high calling that synthesizes natural gifts and abilities and spiritual gifts and abilities into a person who is extremely dedicated and focused.

This book is challenging to me in my own ministry, because I am beginning to recognize the hard work that it is to be a true leader.  It is not something to be taken lightly.  I will study the principles and essential qualities posed in this book much more deeply.

The book is an updated version from 2007. I wanted the original text of the book. The publisher felt the writings were outdated and modern Christians wouldn't understand the archaic references. That's WHY I wanted it. The publisher also made the book gender inclusive. I wanted Sanders' original language so I could be the judge on whether he is taking about 'males' when he says 'man' or the human race.
I am giving five stars as to not hurt the rating review as I know the content will be excellent once I read the original edition.
